case_vignette: A HEALTHY 30-YEAR-OLD MAN PRESENTS WITH A 3-YEAR HISTORY OF AN ASYMPTOMATIC, FLESHY PAPULE AT THE BASE OF HIS GREAT TOE. HE DENIES ANY NEW LESIONS DURING THIS TIME, A HISTORY OF TRAUMA TO THE AREA, OR A FAMILY HISTORY OF SIMILAR SKIN LESIONS. HE WAS TREATED PREVIOUSLY BY ANOTHER DERMATOLOGIST WITH CRYOTHERAPY; HOWEVER, HE RETURNS TO THE CLINIC WITH RECURRENCE OF THE LESION. EXAMINATION REVEALS A PEDUNCULATED, FLESH-COLORED, WELL-DEMARCATED TUMOR ON THE PLANTAR SURFACE OF THE BASE OF HIS GREAT TOE.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a fleshy bump at the base of my big toe.
How long have you had the bump for?
I've had the bump for 3 years.
Has the bump changed in size or appearance over these 3 years?
No, the bump has not changed in size or appearance during this time.
Does the bump cause you any pain or discomfort?
No, the bump does not cause any pain or discomfort.
Do you have any similar bumps elsewhere on your body?
No, I don't have any similar bumps elsewhere on my body.
Final Diagnosis: Piezogenic pedal papules.
